Why in the world are we here?
By ERIC GARLAND
The first of a hopeful series on
The Goals of Undergraduate
Education" was presented last
night in the Listening-Viewing
more than
Room, at
seventy students. Mark
Hertsgaard, leading the forum for
the Student Council, opened the
evening by remarking that a
favorable response would lead to
more sessions throughout the
year.
The presentation featured four
of the more visible members of
the Hopkins faculty -- Ric
Pfeffer, Robert Pond. William
McClain, and Phoebe Stanton -each of whom delivered a short
talk on the murky concepts of
'university" and "education."
Pfeffer began by noting that
Hopkins. typical of American
three primary
universities.
goals: training, bestowing
credentials, and indoctrinating,
the reinforcement of social habits
such as competition and
recognition of authority.
He stressed that the university
Should instead get students to
think critically about society. in

iNs

l
h
TIMi

a detached manner to " generate
the. correct questions about our
lives." For specific examples, he
suggested that courses (now
glaringly absent flom university
curricula) should be given on the
idea of the university, the mass
media, and work in society; the
development of American
capitalism and the Vietnam war
also deserve more attention.
Commenting on the
fragmented nature of
undergraduate education, Pfeffer
St ated that. most courses are
"abstracted from life and,
basically bookwork.- Students
must pursue tactics in education,
Ile emphasized. which would
maximize critical thinking while
protecting them politically. He
closed by remarking that "you
will become educated at this
university primarily not because
of Hopkins, but despite
Hopkins."
Both Pond and McClain
followed with more traditional
views.- Pond defining education as
an "insatiable desire to learn"
and the university supposedly
Providing the necessary tools to

feed that desire; McClain
reflecting on the transition Imin
the classical outline of education
to,•• the Iwo d el-p idea of
"generative" studids (those that
can link one to almost any
subject).
"The real challenge," McClain
said, "in view of the acceleration
(of our age) is to determine what
we can teach and what we can
omit...there's a conflict between
students who know what they
have to do. and we who know
what we have to teach
We're In the Money
Finally, Stanton ventured that
"I think you're here for these
, four years because you can
afford it," drawing the second
largest laugh of the evening.
"You're waiting out an extended
adolescence here,'' she
commented.
On a more positive note, she
emphasized that pleasure should
be a part of education -- "I want
you to enjoy knowing things."
She complained, however. that
much of the faculty "does not
think very well on issues outside
of their own credentialed area.-

Intersession provision requested
By GEORGE B. ZELINSKY
A resolution urging the
Academic Council to in
the provision, by each academic
department, of a specified
minimmn number of Intersession
courses, will be brought before
the Student Council tonight.
Senior Class President Sheldm
Himelfarb, who, along with
Student Assistant to the Dean
Andy Davis, is co-sponsoring the
resolution, asserted that "the
objectives and structure of the
Intersession must be changed in
Order for it to be viable."
The Himelfarb/Davis
resolution calls for a student
referendum to decide the fate of
lntersession. The options to be
put before the student body are:
I.) upgrading the Intersession to
the level where it is acceptable to
both students and faculty; 2.)
maintain the current system; or
3-) return to the pre-Intersession
System of exams in January.
According to Himelfarb,
departments would be given a
Specific number (scaled according
to t he size of the given
department) of courses which
they must make available for the
Intersession period. Based on the
assumption that increased course
Offerings will result in greater
student participation, the
resolution does not provide any
guarantees of increased student
interest. Himelfarb admitted that
a mandatory mini-semester had
been discussed, but that "this
would have gone against the
original purpose and spirit of the

Iii order to
Intersession.
Preclude the possibility of
instructors lecturing to empty
classrooms (at least for the first
few days) the resolution would
also prescribe enrollment
minimums. Himel farb expressed
confidence that increased course
selection would raise student
interest.
The Inter session originally
evolved in 1969 from student
demands for calendar reform. At
that time. Hopkins was operating
under a semester system, with
exams in mid-Janiary, preceded
by a two week "reading period."
Students and faculty argued that
the reading period was a "dead
space" in the school's calendar—a
nine which they claimed could
be used for "an informal
exchange of knowledge" between
professors and students,
unrestricted by considerations of
grades or credits. The SC, after
threatening a student strike, held
a referendum on the "4-1-4" plan
(four months— one month--...).
In what may well have been a
forecast of things to come, only
40 per cent of the 1890 member
student body voted on the
proposal, which was carried by
an overwhelming 94.8 per cent.
Three days later on March 14,
1969, the General Assembly of
the faculty voted 86-26 in favor
of Intersession. Finally, on March
26th, the Academic Council
ratified the plan, with only minor
modifications. A key
consideration in the
Administration's approval was

the plan's congruence to the then
current Goucher College
calendar; it facilitated
cooperation between the two
schools. -After the novelty of the
system began to tarnish, student
interest began to taper off, and
this, in combination with latent
opposition, resulted in
the
widespread disenchantment with
Intersession. The introduction of
credits, in an effort to stimulate
student interest and
participation, met with short
term success, and low enrollment
levels soon reappeared.
A highly-placed University
administrator labeled the
Intersession a "patent failure",
which should be abolished. The
source argued that unless more
than 50 per cent of the students
and faculty participate there
would be no point in continuing
the Intersession.
Groveled
Himelfarb indicated that the
"whole purpose of the proposal
is to put the onus on faculty and
students for the success or failure
of In te rsession...to bring the
matter to a head."
Student Council President
Steve Ponchak concurred with
Himel fa rb's call for assertive
action. He noted that the passive
approach taken by past Student
Councils has been less than
successful. "We've begged and
begged—we've groveled—and
that's not the road we should
have to take for our education
here."

! Pfeffer, Stanton,McClain. Pond

After the individual speeches,
the forum continued in the Glass
Pavilion, where a number of
students spilled out tales of
identity crises and epiphanies
about educational "reality." A
prevailing view of "you're here
for certification" came out
during the open discussion, with
the feeling that 3500 (3700 next
year) bills wete perhaps being
tossed into an irrelevant sinkhole.
As for undergraduate - faculty
relations, Pfeffer commneted
that "professors are conditioned
not to spend too much time with
students...this university is here
to do research; if you don't
spend enough time writing five

pounds of books, you don't gel
promoted, regardless of what
kind of teacher you are.
Everybody on the faculty knows
The relatively large turnout
and genuine concern about the
university's problems signaled a
successful continuation of the
series. At the end of the meeting.
Hertsgaard indicated that inure
specific topics, such as tenure or
student organization. might be
presented in the future. with
more participation from those
faculty members and students
(and even administration figures)
not usually as "out front" as
Monday's speakers

Grades getting high
By MICHEL STEVEN KRUG
The price of steak is not the
only item t hat has become
inflated over the past five years.
A recently released study by the
Hopkins Office of the Registrar
IndicateS that undergraduate
grades continue to, rise at a
steady pace.
To illustrate the rate of grade
inflation. time mean cumulative
grade-point average (CPA) for
fall term 1975, for all
undergraduates, was 3.13. In
'co parison, mean fall CPA's
from 1971-4 were respectively:
2.95, 3.04, 3.08 and 3.14. These
statistics suggest that growing
CPA averages, on the rise since
1956.(when approximately 2.6),
have begun) to stabilize.
Grade distribution for an
aggregate of Arts and Science
departments during fall term,
1975. showed "A's— as the most
prominent mark. A total of 2915
"A's- (28.2 percent) were doled
out as compared to 2682 "B's"
(25.9 percent), 1111 "C's"
10.7 percent) and 168 "D's"
(1.6 percent). Freshmen grades,
not counted towards a CPA
comprised 26.5 percent.
Although some students have
suggested that grades come easier
in the Humanities (11) area of
study, statistics indicate the
number of "A's" and "B's"
received in other areas was
almost identical.
A's" were
n terdepart mental
the most prevalent grade in 60
percent of Humanities
departments, while 57 percent of
other areas. The study shows that
75 percent of all grades issued in
the 1975 academic year were
either "A's" or "B's".
"I don't view the grade
inflation as an infusion of higher
intellects. Students aren't better
than those in the 1960's," said
Sigmund R. Suskind, Dean of
Academic Programs. Ile listed the

reasons for the grade inflation as
follows:
Increased leniency by professors
in asshming grades.
Calculated use by students of the
pass/ fail option lot difikult
classes outside their major.
Widespread use by students of
incompletes to extend their time
to achieve good grades.
Em lessors have also been more
willing to offer this extra time.
The add/drop option which
allows students to choose at a
late date which courses are
easiest.
Increased availabilities of
study
internships. in
courses. and intersession classes
which normally are liberal on
grade decisions.
Other sources pointed to
greater delegation of time by
students to study, the ability of
students to bettel anticipate and
prepare for exam questions, and
cheating.
Sup porting the theory of
erudite study, Frederik Dierman,
Director of Academic
Counseling, said students study
more because of the tight job
market, particularly those
undergraduates who are
pre-meds. "Students realize that
transcripts may be worth
something," Ile said.
Suskind said the
use of the pass/fail option will
probably decrease now because
graduate schools do not accept
grades of this sort.
Both Suskind and Dierman
predict a deflationary trend to
establish itself in the next ten
years. The drop from a 3.14 to
3.13 CPA may support this
assertion.
Asked whether professors have
been instructed to be more strict
in appraising students, Suskind
said no. "They have been asked
to grade as they've always
graded; honestly and unbiased.—

(CPS)—Hold, that course on
Swift!
A book, recently discovered in
an Irish attic, has been proven to
be a copy of Jonathan Swift's
Gulliver's Travels, which the
author himself marked up with
75 corrections which have never
been added to the actual text.
That will change later this fall,
however, when an English
publishing firm brings out a new
version of the work just as Swift
wrote it.
The changes occurred when
Swift's printer, one Ben Motte,
got willies over the tart criticisms

the author had aiMed at a few
-powerful royal targets. Although
Gullver's Travels seems fairly
tame to Twentieth Century
readers, it was hot stuff back in
1726. At one point, Motte
dropped live entire paragraphs
front the text.
Swift himself did some
deleting as well, according to the
British scholar who examined the
newly discovered edition. In a list
of vices which Swift wrote would
disappear if the Houyhnhnms
gained power, - Motte added
"whoring." Swift dropped that
One from his corrected version.

wit!“,ti.t drugs.

In addition, thousands of tiny.

a psychedelic trip. The technique
works on more than 50 per cent
of his patients, the dentist says.

Follett's follies

Council prepares price survey
By BOB BUCHANAN
The Student Council
bookstore task force is preparing
a comparative study of bookstore
Pricing policies, sending out
questionaires to both private
independent and
university-operated bookstores
across the country.
The comparative pricing study
is part of a more complete SC
survey which is to be completed
and presented to the Dean of
Students early in December. The
SC hopes that this report will
Prompt the University into
conducting a sweeping in-depth
analysis of Homewood's Follett's
Book Center. They also want the
University to consider the
Possibility of running the
bookstore on its own.
The comparative study differs
markedly from past surveys of
bookstore prices, conducted by
the SC, News-Letter, and other
Hopkins-affiliated groups,
according to task force
Spokesmen. They contend that
Whereas in the past only area
Private college bookstores pricing
Policies • were examined, this
study will concentrate on
university-run and private

operations in separate geographic
locations. A detailed survey
questionaire will be mailed to
15-20 bookstore operations to
determine the viability of a
, running the
university
bookstore on its own.
Sheldon Himelfarb, who is
heading the SC bookstore task
force, said that George Connolly,
Freshman Class President; Ron
Zagoris, Sophomore Class.
President; and Liam Schwartz,
Junior Class Representative will
comprise the comparative price
survey team.
Their findings will be included
in a full report to be written by
Himelfarb, with the assistance of
six persons solicited from a
student support rally the group
staged last Wednesday. Himelfarb
indicated that.: the ideas and
suggestions of 'these people will
be taken into consideration when
the drafting of the document is
made.
The group's organizer, who is
leading the bookstore effort as
head of the SC's financial aid
committee, said that the report
will take a "point, question,
discussion" format. "We will be
offering the questions to the

Blue Key opens door
By GAYLE COHEN
The Blue Key Society has
increased its membership to more
than 200 as a result of a recent
membership drive, a vital step in
its reorganization and expansion.
The drastic. revamping of Blue
Key's membership qualifications
occurred through its efforts to
increase services to the
Admissions Office. Formerly,
Blue Key had about 40 student
members chosen on the basis of
interviews. Under the new open
policy, the only requirement for
joining is a willingness to work.
Vice-president Barbara Schloss
explained, "We are not an
honorary society anymore.
Anyone who wants to belong to
Blue Key can." However, she
added that Blue Key will retain
its selectivity by closely
monitoring members'
participation.

George Skegas at recent rally

The establishment of
performance guidelines' will also
enable Blue Key to assess its
members' interest. According to
Schloss, such assessment has
always been difficult, with some
students in the past applying to
Blue Key solely for its prestige
value.
Currently, Blue Key's -main
functions consist of giving tours
of the University,
high schools,
visiting
and planning the upcoming
departmental weekends.
Blue Key members daily
conduct three tours of the
campus. In addition, president
George Skegas hopes eventually
to publish direction pamphlets
for visitors who wish to tour the
campus without a guide.
The high school visitations
committee aids the admissions
office in making personal contact
with prospective students by
returning to their high schools to
promote Hopkins. Yet, since
• Blue Key representatives
returning only to their own home
areas, their visits serve more as an
information exchange than as an
aggressive recrultment campaign.
A third Blue Key committee is
coordinating a series of
departmental weekends designed
to publicize a particular area of
study at the university. These
weekends will enable high school
seniors to 'visit the campus and
investigate the academic
departments that interest them.
This program will begin early
next semester with the
= Humanities Weekend,
Blue Key will also supervise
g
73'
the Top 400 program which
.1. brings the 400 most highly
4g qualified applicants to campus in
the spring. This activity was
formerly run by the Admissions
Council.

Dean which need to be answered,
hoping that this will bring about
inner action." Himelfarb said
that while his group will attempt
to offer some observation on the
questions they pose to the Dean,
they will be largely for the
purpose of fomenting further
response.
Profits
The effort to have the
University take another look at
Follett's and consider running
the bookstore by itself is based
on the suspicion that Follett's is
making a profit at Homewood.
The -SC maintains that if this is
true, the University should then
take over the operation and add
the profit to University coffers.
However, apparently the
University does not know, at this
time, if Follett's is making a
profit. Himelfarb said that Bettye
Miller, Business Manager of the
Dean of Student's Office,
possesses little knowledge of
Follett's financial ledger and has
not ascertained their profit
margin, if one exists.
Follett's manager Jim Ehle
continues to state publicly that
in fact the Book Center is not
making a profit, and that it has
suffered a loss over the past two
years. Ellie, who met with
Himelfarb and SC President
Ponchak last week, also said that
any comparative price survey will
show the Book Center "doing
reasonably well." "If the study
does not show that then it will
pose a problem," the manager
said. "But," he continued, "I'm
confident that our prices are
competitive."

Wurds, muds, wurus

While respecting the autonomy
which he feels the SC must enjoy
in preparing their report, Ellie
said, "I want to put my two bits
in, and then let them go any way
they want to on this."
Dean of Students Jakie - Hall
says that last week he talked 'to
both Himelfarb and Ponchak on
the bookstore situation. He said
that while he began talking to
Follett's last spring about
possible problems which were
being mentioned by Students, he
has not previously benefitted
from student input. Hall added
that the reason he has not taken
action against Follett's has been
that his office has not
"discovered any wrongdoing
there."

Ehle said that he had received
a formal apology from both
Ponchak and Himelfarb,
regarding' their failure to notify
him before last Wednesday's
criticism University-Book Center
relations. Earlier, Ellie had said
that Ponchak had promised him
that he would be notified prior
to the SC's promoting any
activity involving Pollen's.
Additionally, Ellie said that he
wants to advise the SC bookstore
task force on (he unique aspects
of the Hopkins situation and
make them aware of several
nuances of the bookstore
business in general. He feels that
the committee should be aware
of these items prior to
conducting the investigation.

Political Economy adds Walters
By STEPHEN LEVIN
The Hopkins Department of
Political Economy pulled a major

referendum
in keeping with what has in recent years become a
Thanksgiving tradition on the order of the Armv-Navy game
or maybe cranberries, the masses at Hopkins cry out to their
leaders and the pofvers diat 'be, for that most unattainable
dream -- an intellectually stimulating selection of intersession
Courses.

Intersession as we now know it is a misshapen mutation of
the idealistic, if somewhat ill-conceived, plan for informal
scholarly intercourse between students and faculty which
spra ng from the waning days ,of the six ties. It should be
apparent to all concerne(1. that in light of the many
deviations from die original mandate. lntersession is in a
pathetic shambles and is a mockery of what it was intended
to be.
The solution is self-evident: created by a student
referendum, lntersession should now be re-evaluated in the
same manlier. Whether the student body chooses to retain
the 'system with an implicit commitment to reform and
strengthen lntersession or dispose of it *turning thereby to
the previous arrangement with examinations,in January) it is
imperative that the decision be made without delay.. The
current condition of stagnation is of benefit to no one, and
detrimental to all.
Therefore it is essential that the Student Council quickly
take the steps necessary to implement at least the first part of
the Himelfarb/Dayis proposal - a student referendum to
decirle the fate of the in,tersession.

letters to the editor
To the Editor:
Because of the SAC's decision
to review budget requests early
this year, there will be a meeting
f the women's center
Wednesday night, Nov. .17 at
7:30 p.m. in the basement of
Roger's House, 3506. Greenway.
The meeting will address the
present status and the future of
the women's center at Hopkins.
Interested members of the
Hopkins community are
requested to attend.
It is our proposal that the
present women's center budget
of S2800 be reduced to S300.
This decision has been made on
the basis of a lack of response
from the men and women of the
Hopkins community. In spite of
frequent requests for ideas or
feedback and despite repeated
offers of time, energy and
resources, there has been no
communication of interest or
energy to the women's center.
The one exception to this is the
discussion and development of
women's studies courses. We feel
that the ongoing support of this
dialogue is important and
justifies our budget request.
The lack of energy and
commitment to the issues of sex
roles and status that face all of us
is surprising 6.5% of the Hopkins
faculty is female. Nine of the 212
full professors are women. In
spite of a recent spurt of new
faculty positions, the ratio of
women faculty has decreased in
the last four years. 28% of the
undergraduate student body is
female. 30% of the graduate
student population is female.
Senseless barricrs remain between
members of the Hopkins and

Goucher communities. Instead of
developing a positive means of
communication. women
atHopkins share no community,
remaining isolated and divided.
Our disappointment in the
lack of discussion of these issues,
at any level, is evident. We hope
that these feelings are shared by
others in the university.
Wednesday night's meeting is an
opportunity to express, share and
act on those feelings.
Susan Lynch
Martha McGloin
Marie Nally

Why in the world are we here?
By ERIC GARLAND
The first of a hopeful series on
The Goals of Undergraduate
Education" was presented last
night in the Listening-Viewing
more than
Room, at
seventy students. Mark
Hertsgaard, leading the forum for
the Student Council, opened the
evening by remarking that a
favorable response would lead to
more sessions throughout the
year.
The presentation featured four
of the more visible members of
the Hopkins faculty -- Ric
Pfeffer, Robert Pond. William
McClain, and Phoebe Stanton -each of whom delivered a short
talk on the murky concepts of
'university" and "education."
Pfeffer began by noting that
Hopkins. typical of American
three primary
universities.
goals: training, bestowing
credentials, and indoctrinating,
the reinforcement of social habits
such as competition and
recognition of authority.
He stressed that the university
Should instead get students to
think critically about society. in

iNs

l
h
TIMi

a detached manner to " generate
the. correct questions about our
lives." For specific examples, he
suggested that courses (now
glaringly absent flom university
curricula) should be given on the
idea of the university, the mass
media, and work in society; the
development of American
capitalism and the Vietnam war
also deserve more attention.
Commenting on the
fragmented nature of
undergraduate education, Pfeffer
St ated that. most courses are
"abstracted from life and,
basically bookwork.- Students
must pursue tactics in education,
Ile emphasized. which would
maximize critical thinking while
protecting them politically. He
closed by remarking that "you
will become educated at this
university primarily not because
of Hopkins, but despite
Hopkins."
Both Pond and McClain
followed with more traditional
views.- Pond defining education as
an "insatiable desire to learn"
and the university supposedly
Providing the necessary tools to

feed that desire; McClain
reflecting on the transition Imin
the classical outline of education
to,•• the Iwo d el-p idea of
"generative" studids (those that
can link one to almost any
subject).
"The real challenge," McClain
said, "in view of the acceleration
(of our age) is to determine what
we can teach and what we can
omit...there's a conflict between
students who know what they
have to do. and we who know
what we have to teach
We're In the Money
Finally, Stanton ventured that
"I think you're here for these
, four years because you can
afford it," drawing the second
largest laugh of the evening.
"You're waiting out an extended
adolescence here,'' she
commented.
On a more positive note, she
emphasized that pleasure should
be a part of education -- "I want
you to enjoy knowing things."
She complained, however. that
much of the faculty "does not
think very well on issues outside
of their own credentialed area.-

Intersession provision requested
By GEORGE B. ZELINSKY
A resolution urging the
Academic Council to in
the provision, by each academic
department, of a specified
minimmn number of Intersession
courses, will be brought before
the Student Council tonight.
Senior Class President Sheldm
Himelfarb, who, along with
Student Assistant to the Dean
Andy Davis, is co-sponsoring the
resolution, asserted that "the
objectives and structure of the
Intersession must be changed in
Order for it to be viable."
The Himelfarb/Davis
resolution calls for a student
referendum to decide the fate of
lntersession. The options to be
put before the student body are:
I.) upgrading the Intersession to
the level where it is acceptable to
both students and faculty; 2.)
maintain the current system; or
3-) return to the pre-Intersession
System of exams in January.
According to Himelfarb,
departments would be given a
Specific number (scaled according
to t he size of the given
department) of courses which
they must make available for the
Intersession period. Based on the
assumption that increased course
Offerings will result in greater
student participation, the
resolution does not provide any
guarantees of increased student
interest. Himelfarb admitted that
a mandatory mini-semester had
been discussed, but that "this
would have gone against the
original purpose and spirit of the

Iii order to
Intersession.
Preclude the possibility of
instructors lecturing to empty
classrooms (at least for the first
few days) the resolution would
also prescribe enrollment
minimums. Himel farb expressed
confidence that increased course
selection would raise student
interest.
The Inter session originally
evolved in 1969 from student
demands for calendar reform. At
that time. Hopkins was operating
under a semester system, with
exams in mid-Janiary, preceded
by a two week "reading period."
Students and faculty argued that
the reading period was a "dead
space" in the school's calendar—a
nine which they claimed could
be used for "an informal
exchange of knowledge" between
professors and students,
unrestricted by considerations of
grades or credits. The SC, after
threatening a student strike, held
a referendum on the "4-1-4" plan
(four months— one month--...).
In what may well have been a
forecast of things to come, only
40 per cent of the 1890 member
student body voted on the
proposal, which was carried by
an overwhelming 94.8 per cent.
Three days later on March 14,
1969, the General Assembly of
the faculty voted 86-26 in favor
of Intersession. Finally, on March
26th, the Academic Council
ratified the plan, with only minor
modifications. A key
consideration in the
Administration's approval was

the plan's congruence to the then
current Goucher College
calendar; it facilitated
cooperation between the two
schools. -After the novelty of the
system began to tarnish, student
interest began to taper off, and
this, in combination with latent
opposition, resulted in
the
widespread disenchantment with
Intersession. The introduction of
credits, in an effort to stimulate
student interest and
participation, met with short
term success, and low enrollment
levels soon reappeared.
A highly-placed University
administrator labeled the
Intersession a "patent failure",
which should be abolished. The
source argued that unless more
than 50 per cent of the students
and faculty participate there
would be no point in continuing
the Intersession.
Groveled
Himelfarb indicated that the
"whole purpose of the proposal
is to put the onus on faculty and
students for the success or failure
of In te rsession...to bring the
matter to a head."
Student Council President
Steve Ponchak concurred with
Himel fa rb's call for assertive
action. He noted that the passive
approach taken by past Student
Councils has been less than
successful. "We've begged and
begged—we've groveled—and
that's not the road we should
have to take for our education
here."

! Pfeffer, Stanton,McClain. Pond

After the individual speeches,
the forum continued in the Glass
Pavilion, where a number of
students spilled out tales of
identity crises and epiphanies
about educational "reality." A
prevailing view of "you're here
for certification" came out
during the open discussion, with
the feeling that 3500 (3700 next
year) bills wete perhaps being
tossed into an irrelevant sinkhole.
As for undergraduate - faculty
relations, Pfeffer commneted
that "professors are conditioned
not to spend too much time with
students...this university is here
to do research; if you don't
spend enough time writing five

pounds of books, you don't gel
promoted, regardless of what
kind of teacher you are.
Everybody on the faculty knows
The relatively large turnout
and genuine concern about the
university's problems signaled a
successful continuation of the
series. At the end of the meeting.
Hertsgaard indicated that inure
specific topics, such as tenure or
student organization. might be
presented in the future. with
more participation from those
faculty members and students
(and even administration figures)
not usually as "out front" as
Monday's speakers

Grades getting high
By MICHEL STEVEN KRUG
The price of steak is not the
only item t hat has become
inflated over the past five years.
A recently released study by the
Hopkins Office of the Registrar
IndicateS that undergraduate
grades continue to, rise at a
steady pace.
To illustrate the rate of grade
inflation. time mean cumulative
grade-point average (CPA) for
fall term 1975, for all
undergraduates, was 3.13. In
'co parison, mean fall CPA's
from 1971-4 were respectively:
2.95, 3.04, 3.08 and 3.14. These
statistics suggest that growing
CPA averages, on the rise since
1956.(when approximately 2.6),
have begun) to stabilize.
Grade distribution for an
aggregate of Arts and Science
departments during fall term,
1975. showed "A's— as the most
prominent mark. A total of 2915
"A's- (28.2 percent) were doled
out as compared to 2682 "B's"
(25.9 percent), 1111 "C's"
10.7 percent) and 168 "D's"
(1.6 percent). Freshmen grades,
not counted towards a CPA
comprised 26.5 percent.
Although some students have
suggested that grades come easier
in the Humanities (11) area of
study, statistics indicate the
number of "A's" and "B's"
received in other areas was
almost identical.
A's" were
n terdepart mental
the most prevalent grade in 60
percent of Humanities
departments, while 57 percent of
other areas. The study shows that
75 percent of all grades issued in
the 1975 academic year were
either "A's" or "B's".
"I don't view the grade
inflation as an infusion of higher
intellects. Students aren't better
than those in the 1960's," said
Sigmund R. Suskind, Dean of
Academic Programs. Ile listed the

reasons for the grade inflation as
follows:
Increased leniency by professors
in asshming grades.
Calculated use by students of the
pass/ fail option lot difikult
classes outside their major.
Widespread use by students of
incompletes to extend their time
to achieve good grades.
Em lessors have also been more
willing to offer this extra time.
The add/drop option which
allows students to choose at a
late date which courses are
easiest.
Increased availabilities of
study
internships. in
courses. and intersession classes
which normally are liberal on
grade decisions.
Other sources pointed to
greater delegation of time by
students to study, the ability of
students to bettel anticipate and
prepare for exam questions, and
cheating.
Sup porting the theory of
erudite study, Frederik Dierman,
Director of Academic
Counseling, said students study
more because of the tight job
market, particularly those
undergraduates who are
pre-meds. "Students realize that
transcripts may be worth
something," Ile said.
Suskind said the
use of the pass/fail option will
probably decrease now because
graduate schools do not accept
grades of this sort.
Both Suskind and Dierman
predict a deflationary trend to
establish itself in the next ten
years. The drop from a 3.14 to
3.13 CPA may support this
assertion.
Asked whether professors have
been instructed to be more strict
in appraising students, Suskind
said no. "They have been asked
to grade as they've always
graded; honestly and unbiased.—

(CPS)—Hold, that course on
Swift!
A book, recently discovered in
an Irish attic, has been proven to
be a copy of Jonathan Swift's
Gulliver's Travels, which the
author himself marked up with
75 corrections which have never
been added to the actual text.
That will change later this fall,
however, when an English
publishing firm brings out a new
version of the work just as Swift
wrote it.
The changes occurred when
Swift's printer, one Ben Motte,
got willies over the tart criticisms

the author had aiMed at a few
-powerful royal targets. Although
Gullver's Travels seems fairly
tame to Twentieth Century
readers, it was hot stuff back in
1726. At one point, Motte
dropped live entire paragraphs
front the text.
Swift himself did some
deleting as well, according to the
British scholar who examined the
newly discovered edition. In a list
of vices which Swift wrote would
disappear if the Houyhnhnms
gained power, - Motte added
"whoring." Swift dropped that
One from his corrected version.

Blue Key opens door
By GAYLE COHEN
The Blue Key Society has
increased its membership to more
than 200 as a result of a recent
membership drive, a vital step in
its reorganization and expansion.
The drastic. revamping of Blue
Key's membership qualifications
occurred through its efforts to
increase services to the
Admissions Office. Formerly,
Blue Key had about 40 student
members chosen on the basis of
interviews. Under the new open
policy, the only requirement for
joining is a willingness to work.
Vice-president Barbara Schloss
explained, "We are not an
honorary society anymore.
Anyone who wants to belong to
Blue Key can." However, she
added that Blue Key will retain
its selectivity by closely
monitoring members'
participation.

George Skegas at recent rally

The establishment of
performance guidelines' will also
enable Blue Key to assess its
members' interest. According to
Schloss, such assessment has
always been difficult, with some
students in the past applying to
Blue Key solely for its prestige
value.
Currently, Blue Key's -main
functions consist of giving tours
of the University,
high schools,
visiting
and planning the upcoming
departmental weekends.
Blue Key members daily
conduct three tours of the
campus. In addition, president
George Skegas hopes eventually
to publish direction pamphlets
for visitors who wish to tour the
campus without a guide.
The high school visitations
committee aids the admissions
office in making personal contact
with prospective students by
returning to their high schools to
promote Hopkins. Yet, since
• Blue Key representatives
returning only to their own home
areas, their visits serve more as an
information exchange than as an
aggressive recrultment campaign.
A third Blue Key committee is
coordinating a series of
departmental weekends designed
to publicize a particular area of
study at the university. These
weekends will enable high school
seniors to 'visit the campus and
investigate the academic
departments that interest them.
This program will begin early
next semester with the
= Humanities Weekend,
Blue Key will also supervise
g
73'
the Top 400 program which
.1. brings the 400 most highly
4g qualified applicants to campus in
the spring. This activity was
formerly run by the Admissions
Council.

Profits
The effort to have the
University take another look at
Follett's and consider running
the bookstore by itself is based
on the suspicion that Follett's is
making a profit at Homewood.
The -SC maintains that if this is
true, the University should then
take over the operation and add
the profit to University coffers.
However, apparently the
University does not know, at this
time, if Follett's is making a
profit. Himelfarb said that Bettye
Miller, Business Manager of the
Dean of Student's Office,
possesses little knowledge of
Follett's financial ledger and has
not ascertained their profit
margin, if one exists.
Follett's manager Jim Ehle
continues to state publicly that
in fact the Book Center is not
making a profit, and that it has
suffered a loss over the past two
years. Ellie, who met with
Himelfarb and SC President
Ponchak last week, also said that
any comparative price survey will
show the Book Center "doing
reasonably well." "If the study
does not show that then it will
pose a problem," the manager
said. "But," he continued, "I'm
confident that our prices are
competitive."

Wurds, muds, wurus

While respecting the autonomy
which he feels the SC must enjoy
in preparing their report, Ellie
said, "I want to put my two bits
in, and then let them go any way
they want to on this."
Dean of Students Jakie - Hall
says that last week he talked 'to
both Himelfarb and Ponchak on
the bookstore situation. He said
that while he began talking to
Follett's last spring about
possible problems which were
being mentioned by Students, he
has not previously benefitted
from student input. Hall added
that the reason he has not taken

there."

criticism University-Book Center

activity involving Pollen's.

wants to advise the SC bookstore
task force on (he unique aspects
of the Hopkins situation and
make them aware of several
nuances of the bookstore
business in general. He feels that
the committee should be aware
of these items prior to
conducting the investigation.

referendum
in keeping with what has in recent years become a
Thanksgiving tradition on the order of the Armv-Navy game
or maybe cranberries, the masses at Hopkins cry out to their
leaders and the pofvers diat 'be, for that most unattainable
dream -- an intellectually stimulating selection of intersession
Courses.

Intersession as we now know it is a misshapen mutation of
the idealistic, if somewhat ill-conceived, plan for informal
scholarly intercourse between students and faculty which
spra ng from the waning days ,of the six ties. It should be
apparent to all concerne(1. that in light of the many
deviations from die original mandate. lntersession is in a
pathetic shambles and is a mockery of what it was intended
to be.
The solution is self-evident: created by a student
referendum, lntersession should now be re-evaluated in the
same manlier. Whether the student body chooses to retain
the 'system with an implicit commitment to reform and
strengthen lntersession or dispose of it *turning thereby to
the previous arrangement with examinations,in January) it is
imperative that the decision be made without delay.. The
current condition of stagnation is of benefit to no one, and
detrimental to all.
Therefore it is essential that the Student Council quickly
take the steps necessary to implement at least the first part of
the Himelfarb/Dayis proposal - a student referendum to
decirle the fate of the in,tersession.

letters to the editor
To the Editor:
Because of the SAC's decision
to review budget requests early
this year, there will be a meeting
f the women's center
Wednesday night, Nov. .17 at
7:30 p.m. in the basement of
Roger's House, 3506. Greenway.
The meeting will address the
present status and the future of
the women's center at Hopkins.
Interested members of the
Hopkins community are
requested to attend.
It is our proposal that the
present women's center budget
of S2800 be reduced to S300.
This decision has been made on
the basis of a lack of response
from the men and women of the
Hopkins community. In spite of
frequent requests for ideas or
feedback and despite repeated
offers of time, energy and
resources, there has been no
communication of interest or
energy to the women's center.
The one exception to this is the
discussion and development of
women's studies courses. We feel
that the ongoing support of this
dialogue is important and
justifies our budget request.
The lack of energy and
commitment to the issues of sex
roles and status that face all of us
is surprising 6.5% of the Hopkins
faculty is female. Nine of the 212
full professors are women. In
spite of a recent spurt of new
faculty positions, the ratio of
women faculty has decreased in
the last four years. 28% of the
undergraduate student body is
female. 30% of the graduate
student population is female.
Senseless barricrs remain between
members of the Hopkins and

Goucher communities. Instead of
developing a positive means of
communication. women
atHopkins share no community,
remaining isolated and divided.
Our disappointment in the
lack of discussion of these issues,
at any level, is evident. We hope
that these feelings are shared by
others in the university.
Wednesday night's meeting is an
opportunity to express, share and
act on those feelings.
Susan Lynch
Martha McGloin
Marie Nally
